awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC FRP:  Multi-Scale Modeling of Rubber/Road Contact and Adhesion
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this I/UCRC Fundamental Research Program project is to develop a mathematical model of the tire-road contact characteristics. The specific goals of the project are (1) develop and implement a theory to describe the contact mechanical processes and the resulting friction properties; (2) expand upon the existing physically motivated rubber friction theories; (3) develop multi-scale representation of the rough surface in terms of a self-affine fractal description; and (4) conduct experimental testing and validation of the proposed model in the laboratory and on the track.

Tires are a critical component in the overall automotive system, enabling safety and fuel economy. The research itself will have impact on the new tire compound development research. The model and the test bed will simplify a host of experiments and make possible many others that are otherwise prohibitively complex. The work is supported by the Industry Advisory Board as well as individual industry members of the center and has the potential to extend the center?s portfolio while potentially attracting new members. The results of the research will become part of the material in the ongoing Tire Mechanics course and other courses in Mechanical Engineering. The activities will dovetail with the Virginia Tech Center for Engineering Education and Diversity (CEED) to engage women and minorities to continue toward advanced degrees

por.por_cntn:
The physics behind modeling friction is very complex and when a material such as rubber is involved, this phenomenon becomes much more complex. Understanding how tires generate friction forces while moving on the road surface is directly linked with being able to improve the performance and safety of the vehicle. The complexity of this model development arises from the fact that material properties of the rubber as well as the road surface, its macro and micro structure and if the surface is wet or dry, must be taken into consideration. The investigators researched and developed a new model to estimate the friction coefficient between any tire and any road surface as long as the material properties of the tire tread compound and the profile of the road can be characterized. To characterize the tire material properties, tire companies were contacted and material properties were obtained from Bridgestone Tire Company. To measure the road profile, a portable profilometer was purchased and was used for this purpose. In order to validate the model, a dynamic friction test apparatus was designed and built at the Center for Tire Research (CenTiRe). This model can be used to develop new tread materials for improved tire performance. The extension of this model is currently being developed at CenTiRe to estimate tire tread wear on various road surfaces. The project resulted in one master and one PhD  degrees and three journal and conference papers.
